Problem:
Consider a system governed by the heat equation \\( u_t = \\Delta u \\), where \\( u(t,x) \\) is the temperature distribution over a domain. We investigate the effect of introducing a source term \\( S(x) \\) applied from time t = 0, described mathematically as \\( u_t = \\Delta u + S(x) \\).

If at a certain time \\( t_1 < T \\), a modification of the boundary condition or an additional source term \\( S_2(x) \\) is introduced, will the temperature distribution \\( u(T,x) \\) be only dependent on the original source term \\( S(x) \\)?
Explanation: Introducing a new source term \\( S_2(x) \\) or altering the boundary conditions at time \\( t_1 \\) can significantly influence the system dynamics and the resulting temperature distribution. The effects of \\( S(x) \\) and \\( S_2(x) \\) and any change in boundary condition accumulate, influence diffusion, and affect the final state \\( u(T,x) \\), making it dependent on more than just the original source term.
